posts.title: Kuz-Ram and other models for fragmentation estimation in blasting
posts.text: The Kuz-Ram fragmentation model was developed in the early 1980s by A. Kuznetsov and C. Ramstrom. It is a semi-empirical model used to predict the rock fragmentation size distribution resulting from drilling and blasting operations in mining, quarrying, and construction. The main premise of the model is that the size distribution of fragmented rock is determined by a combination of blasthole parameters (such as diameter, burden, and spacing), explosive energy, and the rockâ€™s inherent properties (e.g., its strength and structure). The Kuz-Ram model uses the following equation to estimate the mean fragment size (ğ‘¥Ì…): ğ‘¥Ì… = ğ´ * (ğ‘… * ğ¸)^(1/6) * ğ‘^(5/6) * ğ‘ ^(1/3) Where: ğ‘¥Ì… is the mean fragment size ğ´ is a constant that depends on the rock properties and blast design parameters ğ‘… is the rock factor, which accounts for the influence of rock properties on fragmentation ğ¸ is the specific charge (the amount of explosive energy per unit volume of rock) ğ‘ is the burden (the distance between the blasthole and the free face of the rock) ğ‘  is the spacing (the distance between blastholes) I draft a calculation tool here for you to calculate the Kuz Ram x50 and other 2 models easily. $("#B50").text(B50.toFixed(2)); } KUZ RAM MODEL CALCU Rcok condtion: UCS(MPa): Young's module(GPa): Poisson ratio: P-wave velocity (m/s): Rock density: Mean joint spacing (m): Joints dip with respect to free face: Blasting Parameters Grid Burden: Grid Spacing: Bench height(m): Hole inclination Stemming(m): Sub-drilling(m): hole diameter(mm): Mean drilling error: Explosive Type(optional): Energy(MJ/kg): Density(g/cm3): VOD(m/s): In-row delay(ms): Scatter of det(ms): Kuz ram setup: KZMJPS: KZMJPA: KZMC(A): KZMC(n): KCO Setup: KCO Xmax(m): Calculate Output Kuzram: Charge length(m) KZMRDI KZMHF KZMTmax KZMAt KZMQ KZME KZMq KZMRs KZMRMD KZMns KZMA KZMn KZMX50 (mm) CZM Parameters: PCJ(MPa): Ph(MPa): hole radius(m): rc(m): Vc(m3): Fc: nfines: CZM: KCO-b: The Kuz-Ram model is widely used in the mining industry for blast design and fragmentation prediction. However, it has its limitations and relies on empirical relationships, which may not always hold true for complex geological and blasting conditions. Therefore, it is essential to validate the model with actual field data and adjust the parameters accordingly to improve the accuracy of predictions. posts.title: Career development opportunities
posts.text: I would like to share some engineering job positions that have been listed on the official website of the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). These positions primarily exist in European and American countries. It is important to note that the entry requirements for these positions are quite rigorous; however, I am sharing these opportunities with everyone to provide visibility to such prospects. As of now, I have gathered information on a total of 1500 job positions. Below, I have provided a selection of these positions. In the future, I will continue to share more career opportunities on this platform. It is worth mentioning that all the information provided has been sourced directly from official channels. I have also included hyperlinks (blue-colored Chinese job titles) that allow you to access the official website and apply directly for these positions For your interaction easily, I use power BI for the visulization Since you have experienced the Power BI, I would like to share more with this essential data tool Power BI is a powerful business intelligence tool developed by Microsoft that offers a range of features and capabilities for engineers. It allows engineers to analyze, visualize, and share data in a user-friendly and interactive manner. Hereâ€™s an introduction to Power BI and its benefits for engineers: Data Integration: Power BI allows engineers to connect and integrate data from various sources such as databases, spreadsheets, cloud services, and IoT devices. This enables engineers to gather and consolidate data from different systems into a single, unified view for analysis. Data Visualization: Power BI provides a wide array of interactive visualization options, including charts, graphs, maps, and custom visuals. Engineers can use these visual elements to present complex engineering data in a more understandable and meaningful way, enabling them to identify patterns, trends, and anomalies. Real-time Monitoring: Power BI offers real-time data monitoring capabilities, allowing engineers to track live data from sensors, equipment, or any other data source. This is particularly useful in engineering applications where real-time monitoring is crucial, such as industrial processes, manufacturing, or infrastructure management. Advanced Analytics: Power BI incorporates advanced analytics capabilities, including data modeling, data mining, and machine learning. Engineers can leverage these features to perform in-depth analysis, predictive modeling, and anomaly detection, enabling them to make data-driven decisions and identify potential issues or optimization opportunities. Collaboration and Sharing: Power BI facilitates collaboration among engineers by allowing them to share reports, dashboards, and datasets with colleagues or stakeholders. This promotes knowledge sharing, enhances decision-making processes, and fosters a collaborative environment for engineering teams. Mobile Access: Power BI offers mobile applications for iOS and Android devices, enabling engineers to access reports and dashboards on the go. This allows engineers to stay connected to critical data and make informed decisions even when they are away from their desks. Integration with Other Tools: Power BI seamlessly integrates with other Microsoft products such as Excel, Azure, and SharePoint. Engineers can leverage these integrations to leverage their existing data sources and workflows, making it easier to incorporate Power BI into their existing engineering processes. In summary, Power BI is an excellent tool for engineers as it empowers them to analyze and visualize engineering data effectively, monitor real-time information, collaborate with colleagues, and make data-driven decisions. With its wide range of features and integrations, Power BI can enhance the productivity and efficiency of engineering teams across various industries.

They are a subset of heavy-tailed distributions. Itâ€™s easy to visualize the idea of a long tailed function, and slightly harder to make it concrete. If we want to be rigorous, though, there is a exact mathematical definition of a long tailed function (Foss et. al, 2013): (ultimately positive) function f is defined according to a limit â€”a term introduced in calculus. Very basically, the limit tells you where the distribution converges to at a certain point. In this case, if the ratio of x + y and x converge to 1 as the x-values get much larger, then the distribution is long-tailed: e long tailed property of distributions carries over into many derivative distributions. If f1, f2â€¦ fn are all long tailed, then: Any distribution that can be expressed as a product of these, fx= f1 Â· f2â€¦ Â· fn is also long tailed. Any distribution that can be expressed as a linear combination of these is long tailed. That means that any function Commerce and marketing schemes often find that there sales can best be modeled by long tail distributions. For instance, an internet store may have certain items with very high sales (modeled by the center of the distribution curve) and a large number of items with much lower sales (modeled by the long tail). Although the sales volume for every individual item in the tail may be negligible, there are enough items that they play a significant role in the general profit taking. In fact, the profit from low-sale volume items can rival or even sometimes leave in the dust the profit made from best-sellersâ€”provided only the tail is long enough. 2.3é•¿å°¾åˆ†å¸ƒåº”ç”¨åœ¨ç”µå•†å¹³å°2.3.1 äºšé©¬é€Šå¹³å°å¯¹äºå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„è¡Œä¸šè½¯ä»¶ï¼Œå¦‚å–å®¶ç²¾çµï¼Œæ•°æ´¾ï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ˜¯æ ¹æ®åæ¯”ä¾‹å‡½æ•°ç»“åˆæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ æ¥æ ¹æ®Bsr æ’åçš„æƒé‡æ¥åæ¨é”€é‡ã€‚ To people that donâ€™t understand them, they manifest as â€˜unfairnessâ€™, which they are. Unlike normal distributions, long tailed phenomena do not centre around a mid-point. Theyâ€™re totally unsymmetrical and extreme events are rare, unpredictable but have gargantuan impacts when they eventually occur. There are two models that we can use to map-out how these long-tailed distributions occur. Preferential attachment: Imagine a network consisting of nodes and connections between nodes. The more connected a node is, the more likely it is to receive new links [3]. Preferential attachment often plays out in social domains. Looking at Instagram as an example, if you think about accounts as nodes and followers as connections; the more followers an account has, the more likely it is to receive more followers. The distribution of followers across social media accounts is a likely long tailed. Self-organized Criticality: Imagine an empty N by N grid. A random site on the grid is chosen, if empty the site grows a tree with a probability g. If a site contains a tree lightening hits the site with a probability of (1-g). The lightening struck tree catches fire and the fire spreads to all connected trees[1]. In plain English, most forest fires are small but there exists a point where the forest becomes so dense that a fire could be gigantic. Hereâ€™s a cool simulation of self-organized criticality playing out in the forest fire model. Taking earthquakes as an example of a phenomenon that roughly follows a power law distribution with an exponent of 2[1]. An earthquake of magnitude 9 would be the size of the 2011 earthquake in Honshu Japan. It was estimated to have killed around 29,000 people and damaged nuclear reactors [5]. According to our assumptions about the distribution of earthquakes, an earthquake of this magnitude occurs with a probability of around one-in-a-million each day. Across 1 century this one in a million event has a probability of occurrence of around 3.5%. Given the devastation that it could cause, suddenly this seems very concerning. It becomes even more so when you realise that the most earthquakes are between 5â€“5.9 on the Richter scale [6], a-thousand to ten-thousand times weaker than our one-in-a-million event. Lack of awareness of long tailed phenomena will cause governments to be ill-prepared for these extreme events leading to mass destruction. LongDim min1 As Long, min2 As Long, min3 As Long, minmin As Long, MaxL As Longstring1_length = Len(string1): string2_length = Len(string2)distance(0, 0) = 0For i = 1 To string1_length: distance(i, 0) posts.title: First to Data Analyst
posts.text: Data AnalystFor data analysis, I think the most important thing is to clarify the business goals, identify the gaps with the goals, and determine the problems that need to be solved. Core Issue 1: Defining the problem - Identifying the reasons for the gap (requires analytical ability and business sense, both personally and on average for peers) Core Issue 2: Cause analysis - After finding possible reasons, refine the indicators Core Issue 3: Analyzing indicators - Find the necessary data to support the analysis (how to find it depends on how to utilize tools) Core Issue 4: Data analysis - Analysis methods Core Issue 5: Solution testing - Once the cause is hypothesized, how to judge if the assumption is correct and proceed with the experiment Core Issue 6: Continuous improvement - How to find predictive indicators to prevent similar problems from recurring and detect them early For example, when analyzing the overspending of advertising budget: First, you need to realize that the problem you are analyzing is overspending. Did you have a definition for overspending previously? Then, what are the reasons? Sales Price Conversion Bidding Increase in bidding Overall increase? Local increase? factors? Market factors? A particular department is having a problem; which product in the department? How to prevent it? Why do it? What to do? How to do it? As for SQL statements, such as: Execution order Table additions, deletions, and reductions, primary key PID Aggregate functions Date conversion Table joins Window functions Sliding window functions Row and column transformations In the era of GPT, is this really important?

posts.title: How do I think â€œReadingâ€
posts.text: How do I think â€œReadingâ€Concept Before discussing a concept, letâ€™s first define its connotation, extension, and the boundaries of the discussion. My understanding of â€œreadingâ€ is: as a behavior, obtaining information through text-based media. This information may not have an effect on you. Text-based media Obtaining information Such information may have an impact Example 1: A physics book will tell you the mechanical reasons for the movement of objects. If you start reading, there may be the following outcomes: â€”You donâ€™t understand at all In this case, you are just â€œlookingâ€ at the book, which is not reading. Even if you look at it for ten years, reading hasnâ€™t started yet. â€”You understand, acquire knowledge of mechanics, and comprehend the principles of object movement In this case, you are â€œreading.â€ Perhaps you can understand why high-speed cars have a long braking distance, and why bicycles donâ€™t fall over. Whether or not you can invent a product like a â€œbicycleâ€ is an unknown! â€œTo read or not to readâ€ First, we need to rule out the â€œdonâ€™t understandâ€ problem because thatâ€™s not considered reading. Personally, I categorize reading into three types: Reading as input, outputting some unpredictable results through the brainâ€™s exploration. This is generally referred to as inspiring thinking. Your input may be controlled by others, such as educational reading clubs or recommendations from others. This is more like the popular AI language models. Pros: It may create a wonderful chemical reaction; perhaps youâ€™ll have an epiphany after reading. Cons: If the input is single or even controlled, the output will also be single, perhaps a form of â€œbrainwashing.â€ Advice: If you are often passively required to read, you can explore different types or even completely opposite ones. For example, pairing mainstream books with â€œbanned books.â€ Reading as a tool, flipping through books for a specific goal or problem, thus achieving a problem-solving result. This is a more practical method I use. You could say â€œevery book is beneficial,â€ but itâ€™s very utilitarian. Pros: Books offer a more systematic and accurate explanation of the problem. And it can solve the problem relatively quickly. Especially for broad issues, this method can help you enter the relevant field fastest. Cons: Poor timeliness, especially for cutting-edge problems. For some specific issues, forums may be more efficient. Advice: Stay sensitive and be sure to understand the background of the book first. Reading as a habit, similar to watching TV. I admire those who make reading a habit, especially for non-fiction books. The input of information is not a pleasant process. This type of â€œreadingâ€ might be driven by the dopamine rush from entertaining novel reading or the habit of reading by successful peopleâ€¦ Advice: No advice, as I have little exposure to this. In summary, if you: Donâ€™t expect yourself to have â€œoutput,â€ let alone transform yourself Donâ€™t have a problem that needs solving and donâ€™t like solving problems yourself Then there is no need to read. Suggestions We all live in an environment where high-quality information is scarce. As a method of obtaining information, reading can be considered the most effective means.
